text:
Hi <@URB31QKM4> :wave:
Upfluence offer influencer/ambassador identification - they crawl a brand's own network and reveal influential customers/clients/fans.
Finding these profiles within your brand network usually means they are easier and cheaper to onboard, plus they've got a natural affinity to your brand.
Happy to set up a chat/demo with the team for you :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Hi

Upfluence offer influencer/ambassador identification - they crawl a brand's own network and reveal influential customers/clients/fans.
Finding these profiles within your brand network usually means they are easier and cheaper to onboard, plus they've got a natural affinity to your brand.
Happy to set up a chat/demo with the team for you

text: Thanks Selina, I’ll keep that in my back pocket! We have some influencer identification tools in our team’s product as well but for this project we’re looking for people who are less likely to be part of our audience today--larger creators/internet celebs to participate as talent in an awareness campaign, not necessarily influencers or ambassadors for our product.

text: How do you organize and lay out your content strategy? Is there a specific template you use? From my experience in startup world, the strategy that lives in a Google doc or spreadsheet becomes outdated pretty quickly with company and team objectives changing so often. Ideally, I want something that covers just enough without feeling too rigid or overly comprehensive.

text:
I have built out an entire system in Notion with related databases.

Easy to use for clients and conprehensive for my needs.

I still think there is a place for google sheets. It cant be avoided for kw research/site/ analytics audits.

For some PM too sheets still seems necessary. Utilization for example

text:
We personally don't have a lot of our medical/health content reviewed. However, I've been at a couple companies who did. Generally, it's kind of a "who you know" market where we started reaching out to people in the network of the content teams at those companies.

Now, I run an agency with a lot of health/wellness clients... And I let them be the final say.

FWIW, I believe the two companies where I worked that paid for reviewers paid $125-250 per article review, because the content was written by experience health content writers. No idea if that's really a fair rate, but I figured I'd share.

(Sorry I'm so late to this question — catching up after vaca. :slightly_smiling_face: )

text: With a term or very short definition, I think it makes more sense to use the same phrasing (especially if you're talking about medical stuff). Google will pair the appropriate page with the right search, as long as you're doing well at optimizing each piece for distinct topics.

elements.text: With a term or very short definition, I think it makes more sense to use the same phrasing (especially if you're talking about medical stuff). Google will pair the appropriate page with the right search, as long as you're doing well at optimizing each piece for distinct topics.

text:
I'm an agency owner but I've also worked in-house on a content team that worked with freelancers for different topic areas, so I have thoughts.

(Also, it's a great chat to have with your CEO, although it does sound like it could be a bit nightmarish. :joy: )

My first thought is that it depends on your current in-house team and how much flexibility and time you have for editing, actually publishing articles, outlining, developing a content calendar, etc.

If you've got access to internal editors you really trust, I'd say you could try going the route of hiring freelancers you feel could cover the content well. However, I'd probably start with an agency to come up with a comprehensive content strategy even in that case.

If you're more a one-man show and it feels like that would stretch you to breaking point, I'd suggest going with a content agency. At least in my experience with clients, you'll probably end up having content published more consistently without bogging down projects you can't hire out. That's especially going to help you if you're in charge of repurposing content for multiple channels — getting the long-form pieces written first, without you spending 1 or more days on each, could streamline your process significantly.

An agency would also be helpful in terms of calculating what you get for exact dollars, at least in terms of deliverables (IMO).

If it were me, I'd probably ask questions like:

• *Are you more concerned with building exponential traffic/leads to one source (website, YouTube, email, etc.) or with having existing content on a larger variety of sources?* If he's just hoping to have a lot more organic traffic to the site, then the budget should go to long-form content creation, based on your industry. But if he wants to engage a different channel first, that impacts the budget and whom you work with a LOT.
• *What timeline are you comfortable to wait for results?* If he wants something fast, you'll need to look at paid traffic, but if he's willing to give 3-6 months+ to the efforts, long-form SEO content could work well.
I hope this is helpful!

(Also, it's a great chat to have with your CEO, although it does sound like it could be a bit nightmarish.

)

My first thought is that it depends on your current in-house team and how much flexibility and time you have for editing, actually publishing articles, outlining, developing a content calendar, etc.

If you've got access to internal editors you really trust, I'd say you could try going the route of hiring freelancers you feel could cover the content well. However, I'd probably start with an agency to come up with a comprehensive content strategy even in that case.

If you're more a one-man show and it feels like that would stretch you to breaking point, I'd suggest going with a content agency. At least in my experience with clients, you'll probably end up having content published more consistently without bogging down projects you can't hire out. That's especially going to help you if you're in charge of repurposing content for multiple channels — getting the long-form pieces written first, without you spending 1 or more days on each, could streamline your process significantly.

An agency would also be helpful in terms of calculating what you get for exact dollars, at least in terms of deliverables (IMO).

If it were me, I'd probably ask questions like:
Are you more concerned with building exponential traffic/leads to one source (website, YouTube, email, etc.) or with having existing content on a larger variety of sources?

If he's just hoping to have a lot more organic traffic to the site, then the budget should go to long-form content creation, based on your industry. But if he wants to engage a different channel first, that impacts the budget and whom you work with a LOT.
What timeline are you comfortable to wait for results?
If he wants something fast, you'll need to look at paid traffic, but if he's willing to give 3-6 months+ to the efforts, long-form SEO content could work well.
I hope this is helpful!

text: We use a Google Sheets template for our content calendar and keyword data. The strategy summary we send to clients is generally a PDF, but I get the problem with the constantly changing objectives. I'd probably still use Google Docs (I hate trying to push new/unfamiliar stuff on my clients, who are often not all that tech savvy) but keep it as a living doc with updated strategies each time the team decides a pivot is required.

elements.text: We use a Google Sheets template for our content calendar and keyword data. The strategy summary we send to clients is generally a PDF, but I get the problem with the constantly changing objectives. text: For a definition, you're talking about a small amount of content, so it's not a big deal from an SEO perspective. From a UX perspective it may be different. Does a visitor want to read that definition in so many articles? Doubtful. Your clients are better off building out a glossary. That does have SEO value.
